Available exclusively in Attitude Black paintwork, the new Sport Black Edition brings a distinctive sporty look to Toyota’s fth-generation RAV, and is available in front-wheel-driveguise only.     However, for buyers looking for the added security of an all-wheel-drivedrivetrain in their new RAV, there is the option of AWD in Sol, Sport and Platinum iants, while the entry-level Luna model is FWD only.Petrol Electric PowertrainLike every iant in the RAV range, the Sport Black Edition is powered by a .-litre four-cylinder petrol-electric hybrid powertrain, which produces bhp and Nm of torque and enables the five-seat family SUV to sprint from -km h in just over  seconds. Standard across the entire RAV range is a suite of safety features which offer maximum protection for all occupants, while providing the RAV driver with the latest technology in driver assistance systems.     Collectively called Toyota Safety Sense  , features include Pre-Collision Assistance , Speed Assistance , Lane Keepingand Automatic High Beam Assist.Gracious Exterior, Spacious InteriorThe exterior design of the new RAV is more appealing and less anonymous that its predecessor, and this is gained by way of boxy wheel arches, a squared-off nose with a large grille, and angular edges and creases in the bodywork. I feel that Toyota has done a great job of making the new RAV look and feel more ‘premium’ than ever, while also offering more interior space than any of its predecessors.Cabin quality is exceptional, with sturdy and durable materials used throughout, while overall passenger space is generous in every respect. This has been made possible by placing the front and rear axles mm further apart than before, and even tall adults will be able to sit in the rear seats comfortably, with plenty of legroom and headroom on offer.The RAV’s battery is located under the floor, but its boxy dimensions help to hide it well, with a slightly higher boot floor the only clue to what lies beneath.Compared to its predecessor, the RAV’s boot capacity has grown to -litres , with a massive ,-litres available when the rear seats are folded down.The RAV was awarded a full five stars by Euro NCAP in  and that was thanks in part to an upgrade to the second-generation of Toyota Safety Sense for the latest model.Test CarMy test car was a RAV Sport Black Edition which drew lots of admiring glances due to its terric road presence and distinctive design details.An impressive array of standard equipment includes TEX leather black upholstery with heated front seats, powered driver seat, auto-dimming interior mirror, front and rear parking sensors, rear view camera, auto lights and wipers, LED front light guide with daytime running lights, LED projector headlights, electrically operated boot door, ” Toyota Touch multimedia system, dual zone climate control, rear privacy glass, satellite navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, black headliner cloth, paddle sht, light blue ambient lighting, and illuminated entry along with many more comfort, convenience, safety and infotainment features.As is the case across all models in the RAV line-up, fuel consumption as low as .l km is achievable on a WLTP combined driving cycle, while Co emissions of between  and g kmensures low annual road tax in addition to low overall running costs.Toyota’s advanced hybrid technology ensures that the RAV’s petrol engine and electric motor combine seamlessly to deliver extra performance and outstanding fuel efficiency, while remaining ultra-smooth and extremely quiet when driving in electric mode.Toyota claim that up to % of the time you drive a Toyota Hybrid, you are in electric mode, with the added advantage that you never have to plug the car in to charge the battery.Toyota’s self-charging hybrid harvests the energy normally lost from deceleration and braking into a small battery. This unit doesn’t have enough capacity to propel the RAV alone for any considerable distance, but it does offer the convenience of being able to charge itself without any input from the driver.The RAV sits on Toyota’s New Global Architecture, which is also used in the Toyota Prius, C-HR and Corolla models. It brings big benefits in ride and handling, with more sophisticated suspension than the old model, so the RAV is capable of turning into corners with a surprising amount of poise and precision, with plenty of grip while resisting dramatic levels of body lean.The RAV’s CVTtransmission is smooth and slick in its operation, while a well-insulated cabin ensures that on-road refinement is top class. When travelling through towns and cities at low speed, the RAV’s electric motor is barely audible, with the engine shutting off entirely when stationary in traffic. At motorway cruising speeds, the RAV settles into a quiet hum, with only small amounts of tyre and wind noise getting through to the cabin.Verdict, Cost and WarrantyWith its unique and distinctive modern styling, faultless build quality, impressive tally of standard equipment and frugal petrol electric hybrid technology, the new RAV has all the necessary ingredients to comfortably fulfil the needs of a growing family.The new RAV Sport Black Edition represents great value. The new Toyota RAV is backed by a three-year ,km warranty, along with a five-year ,km warranty on hybrid components.Additionally, a hybrid battery warranty of up to an incredible -years is available upon completing an annual hybrid health check through Toyota’s nationwide dealer network. Based on the A-Class of the time, Mercedes-Benz gave its smallest model some SUV flavour with clever body cladding and a raised ride height.     More SUV-Like Than EverLaunched in , the second-generation GLA also shares its DNA with the latest A-Class, but it gained a more traditional SUV shape. Standing cm taller than its predecessor, the new GLA’s wheel arches are more squared-off in shape and are clad in protective black plastic. Its wheelbase has also been increased to create more passenger space, while the wheels are pushed out to each corner, resulting in much shorter front and rear overhangs.     Pitched directly against rivals like the BMW X and Volvo XC hybrids, the new GLA  e uses the same powertrain as the plug-in A-Class— a .-litre petrol engine and bhp electric motor, drawing power from a .kWh battery. The fuel tank in the GLA  e is located ahead of the car’s front axle, which leaves space under the boot to fit the hybrid battery. Importantly, this means that the GLA avoids the awkward box-shaped intrusion into the boot area seen in some plug-in hybrid cars.Specication DetailsThe new Mercedes-Benz GLA  e is available in a choice of two generously-equipped specication levels — Progressive and AMG Line — both of which come with standard features such as stylish five-twin-spoke light-alloy wheels, parking sensors with reversing camera, LED high performance headlamps, Light and Sight package, hard-disc navigation, MBUX multimedia system, digital radio, Android Auto, Apple CarPlay, Seat Comfort package with heated front seats, automatic climate control, roof liner in black fabric, Mercedes-Benz emergency call system, galvanised steering-wheel gearsht paddles, Easy-Pack tailgate, Dynamic Select, acoustic ambient protection, Active Lane Keep Assist, and Speed Limit Assist, along with many more comfort, convenience and security features.Additional AMG Line specication includes lowered comfort suspension, AMG body styling, carbon-structure trim, ” AMG -twin-spoke light-alloy wheels, Artico leather Dinamica microfibre black upholstery, and AMG floor mats.Test CarMy GLA  e ‘Progressive’ test car was finished in Night Black paintwith contrasting Macchiato Beige Black Artico leather upholsteryfor maximum impact.With a % battery charge, my test car estimated its own electric range to be km’s. The car defaults to Hybrid mode when started up, so you proceed in zero-emission fashion at speeds of up to km h, as long as the battery has charge and you accelerate gently.When the petrol engine cuts in performance is strong, as it and the electric motor combine their power in a smooth and orderly fashion. With a combined power output of bhp and a mighty Nm of torque, the GLA  e can sprint from -km h in as little as . seconds, and can achieve a top speed of km h .The petrol engine only really makes its presence known when you ask for more performance, while neat handling and sufficient grip from the driven front wheels provides great confidence on the road. The car’s steering is light but direct, and the ride is more than comfortable enough to deal with rutted road surfaces and speed ramps with ease.Cabin space is impressive, with excellent head, leg and elbow room available for all occupants, while a -litre boot capacity will be more than adequate for most families. However, the GLA’s standard split-folding rear seat backs allow for the transportation of larger items when called upon, with up to ,-litres of space on offer in this mode.The cabin of the new GLA certainly feels vastly improved over the original GLA in every respect. This has been made possible by the latest Mercedes-Benz MBUX interior layout, with crisp digital displays replacing the analogue instrument dials and flowing across onto the dashboard.Buttons have been largely replaced by a controller ahead of the gear-lever and voice control, which uses articial intelligence similar to that found in home smart devices to recognise more natural speech and commands. The turbine air vents from the original GLA have been retained, but the dashboard has been slimmed-down for a more spacious feel.VerdictOverall, the new Mercedes-Benz GLA  e is a competent all-rounder that offers a decent electric range, low emissions, predictable handling and a luxurious, technology-filled cabin — encased in a stylish and practical premium compact SUV body. They also provide underage hurling via St Patricks, an amalgamation with their parish neighbours St Colms Drum.When Derry won the All-Ireland title in , the countys most successful era, Richard Ferris was part of the winning formula and scored a goal in their opening round against Down that season. Joe Irwin won an Ulster medal with the county and Eunan Rafferty was also on Derry teams in that era.The clubs recent underage development work has provided Michael Mullan to Derrys Ulster minor winning team of , with Tiarnaacuten McHugh, Dara and Ruairi Rafferty part of the group who repeated the feat two seasons later on their way to the All-Ireland Final.Current senior captain Tiarnaacuten Woods has represented Derry at minor and U level, with McHugh and Ruairi Rafferty – who have played senior hurling with Kevin Lynchs – having also played the wee ball game for the county.On the camogie field, Una Rafferty and Aoe Kelly have represented Derry at minor and U level respectively. It has all comeas a result of the work being done at the club.“It is great to have Richard Ferris back involved again,” Shane adds. “He has set up a winter programme in place for the players in first to fth year , with the older players getting looked after under the senior  with their strength and conditioning.”The current senior group has benefited from the influx of youth as they have one eye on the Derry IFC Quarter-Finals later this month.McGonigle paid tribute to those who have sat on club committees down through the years and it has been bolstered with new blood coming on board in recent years to help with the clubs progression. Another great development has been an influx in new coaches coming forward at primary school level. Every bit helps. Like many other clubs across Ireland, Drumsurn reaches deeper into the locality. They are more than just GAA. Its a social hub that knits everyone together, regardless of age. It offers an identity.On top of their day to day club activities and s. Fitness classes, male and female, are a valuable facet of the club, while they also host Irish dancing and bowls.The club has also recently formed a mental health committee and have put in place a full winter program to complement this initiative. There are also plans for Irish language classes. There is never a dull moment. The clubs heart beats strong.“We as a club are very community focused,” Shane stresses. “In the past year we have brought the Action Cancer big bus for two days and also provided a defibrillator in a cabinet for our communitys use.”Since moving to their current premises, Billy Doran Park, in , they have added a training pitch and a club gym.The Club Committee set out a three-phase ground development plan in . The first phase of a new kitchen plus internal and external toilet blocks was completed in  with the changing rooms refurbished in .Phase , currently going through planning, includes a walking track, new floodlights and ball-wall. It all leads into Phase , a floodlit G pitch.“Our proposed ground developments are going to cost in excess of pound,,” McGonigle points out. “For a club of less than  members, this is a massive undertaking.”Drumsurn have set themselves a target of having phases two and three complete for their Centenary Year in .“Unfortunately, as with many other aspects of le, Covid has put a stop to conventional fundraising activities for the moment,” Shane outlines. “So we decided to set up Drumsurn GAC Competitions as a way of raising some much needed funds.” For more information and details on James McClures th minute goal saw the Loup take a healthy six-point lead into the half time break, after the hosts had cut loose during the second quarter. However, St Patricks would not score for another  minutes, and their opponents used the time wisely, chipping away at the lead, with just the goal separating the sides at the second half water break. The Magherafelt side defeated in tonights Jack Cassidy Cup semi final. Loups composure had deserted them and by the time an Eoghan Hawe free reduced the gap to one on  minutes, the side in red looked the more likely winners. Time was on Rossas side, but just as the tide appeared to be turning, Loup rode the wave and hit back, John McClure tapping over a free with five minutes to go to settle the nerves. Aidan McAlynn then slotted another free, and despite a late Magherafelt onslaught that yielded a Dan Higgins point, the hosts held firm to reach a decider against Dungiven. *Full coverage in Tuesdays County Derry Post. title: ‘Fruitful’ meeting with head on school proposal
story: A LOCAL politician has described talks he held last week with the principal of Downpatrickrsquos Blackwater integrated College to discuss plans for a new integrated post-primary school in the area as ldquofruitful and informative.Rowallane DUP councillor Billy Walker, met with the schoolrsquos headmaster, Stephen Taylor last Tuesday, with the talks focusing on a proposal for a new Mid Down College.The steering group behind the new school mdash which could be built between Crossgar and Saintfield mdash has already received over , expressions of interest.The meeting took place after Cllr Walker and other politicians including Strangford MP Jim Shannon and Harry Harvey MLA, expressed concern about the impact the new college would have on number of existing schools mdash St Colmcillersquos High in Crossgar, St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch, Saintfield High and The High School Ballynahinch.Cllr Walker said he outlined his ldquoserious concerns about the new college proposal and the impact it could have on student numbers at neighbouring schools when he met Mr Taylor.ldquoMy biggest fear is that the new Mid Down College has the potential to jeopardise the future of four other schools, he said.ldquoI suggested that instead of building a new school,the integrated proposal does go ahead, it should be based at Down High Schoolrsquos existing Mount Crescent site when it relocates to the Strangford Road in Downpatrick, he said.ldquoBlackwater College is a well established school, but its Old Belfast Road site is landlocked and there is simply no room for expansion, explained Cllr Walker.ldquoMr Taylor made it clear during our meeting thatthe new college proposal does not go ahead, Blackwater will very much remain in business for the long term. If the proposed Mid Down College gets the green light, then it will close and become part of the new school.Cllr Walker said he understood the constraints Blackwater was operating under and that there was no room to expand at its Old Belfast Road site, suggesting that it should also relocate to Down Highrsquos current site when it becomes available.The Rowallane politician has again insisted that he supports integrated education and was behind the proposal to create Drumlins Integrated Primary School in Ballynahinch and Killyleagh Primary Schoolrsquos decision several years ago to embrace integrated status.He said he was ldquoin no way attempting to turn the proposed Mid Down College proposal into a political football, branding such a suggestion as ldquoludicrous.Cllr Walker also rejected claims from Rowallane councillor Patrick Brown that the DUP narrative in the post-primary school proposal was ldquoshort-sighted and  in parts and that the steering group behind the new Mid Down College had no intention of taking students away from other schools.Accusing the Alliance man of being ldquodisingenuous, Cllr Walker said his party is not anti-integrated education.In addition, he rejected Cllr Brownrsquos assertion that Newry, Mourne and Down Council did not want to meet with the Mid Down steering group to discuss its proposal.ldquoIt was agreed that steering group members, along with representatives from the other post-primary schools in the area who have concern about the new college proposal, would be asked to meet with a working group comprising elected representatives to outline their respective views, he said.Cllr Walker said that whatever happened moving forward, childrenrsquos education must always come first as they are the future of the district.He continued: ldquoThe bottom line for me is thatthe proposed Mid Down College impacts on existing schools, I will continue to point that out. We need to consider the needs of all our pupils and their respective futures.Cllr Walker added: ldquoI have met with those for and opposed to the new integrated college proposal and am pleased to have done so as it is the right thing to do. The question I have for Cllr Brown is, has he done likewise .prettyPhoto

title: ‘Traditional Unionist’  McKee joins TUV weeks after his UUP departure
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has its first TUV councillor.Harold McKee mdash who recently quit the UUP over concerns about the leadership of the party under Doug Beattie mdash had intended to become an Independent member of the local authority, but has instead joined the TUV.The veteran Mournes councillor and former South Down MLA, says joining Jim Allisterrsquos party presents him with an opportunity to represent the best interests of the people across his electoral area.This week, Cllr McKee has thanked the many people who have wished him well on his departure from the UUP and his political direction into the future.He explained that since announcing his resignation, he received an overwhelming number of positive messages of support on social media and via phone calls.ldquoI would take this opportunity to thank all those who took the time to message and telephone me, not only local people in Newry Mourne and Down, but also across the whole of Northern Ireland, said Cllr McKee.ldquoIt is often the case when a member leaves a political party that they receive offers from other parties to have a chat with members or indeed the leader to discuss potential future membership. Once again, I would thank those from other unionist parties for their words of encouragement in upholding my Christian faith in the political arena and their offers to have a conversation on my political direction.Cllr McKee confirmed that when he left the UUP, he notied the local councilrsquos chief executiveof his intention to become an Independent councillor for the immediate period to allow some time before deciding where his political future lay.He continued: ldquoWhile I had no intention of making a move to any party anytime soon, I was drawn on the basis of many of my messages and phone calls towards Traditional Unionist Voice.ldquoThis led me to read the TUV policies and manestos which, having read, I believe I am very much in agreement. One of the newspaper articles referred to me as a traditional Unionist and to be honest thatrsquos who I am.Cllr McKee said that following discussions with the TUV leader, Jim Allister, during which he set out the importance of his Christian values as a politician, he has taken up the offer of another party much earlier than he had intended.ldquoLike many people across Northern Ireland, I appreciate the strong and principled leadership Jim has offered, particularly in recent days when it has come to the Northern Ireland Protocol which is undermining our position in the UK, he continued.ldquoI feel that the ethos of TUV and the ever-growing number of members joining the party, particularly in the South Down constituency, provides me with an opportunity to represent the best interests of the people of the Mournes.Welcoming Cllr McKee to the party, Mr Allister said he was delighted that he had decided to join the TUV.ldquoHarold is a conviction politician and as such is a good fit with TUV following his principled resignation from the UUP. I look forward to working with him in pursuit of the interests of the people of the Mournes area, he said..prettyPhoto

title: £500 payment clarity
story: SOUTH MLA Colin McGrath has asked for clarity around a delay to the pound payment promised to independent health and social care staff.The SDLP health spokesperson said that while many health staff began receiving the payments from July, his office had been inundated by staff in care homes, domiciliary care and private hospitals who had yet to receive it.Following representation from Mr McGrath, Stormontrsquos Health Committee has called on Health Minister Robin Swann to brief the committee around the delays to payments.Mr McGrath said: ldquoWhile Irsquom glad that many staff have already received their payment, itrsquos grossly unfair that large numbers have been left waiting as a result of administrative issues.ldquoYou canrsquot hand this money out to some and leave others sitting on their hands with nothing more than an apology.He said that all the health staff across the ious sectors have done tremendous work during the pandemic.He added: ldquoMany staff put themselves at risk of contracting the virus and passing it on to their family and friends, placing themselves under huge strain in the process.ldquoThe problems in administering these payments raise issues around the quality of information stored by the department on our independent health staff and the planning that went into delivering this scheme.ldquoI will be seeking assurances from Health Minister Robin Swann around the delivery of this scheme to ensure that everyone gets the payment they are entitled to as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Arkle and Collins’ make winning start as Downpatrick Pool League returns
story: FITZPATRICKrsquoS B............................COLLINSrsquo.........................................CONOR Vize gave Fitzpatrickrsquos a dream start when he overcame Chris Gordon in the opening game of the match.Adrian Galbraith levelled the scores after he defeated Bunter Cahill, before Chris Quinn shot Collinsrsquo into a lead they would never relinquish by beating Patrick Ferris.Chris Quinn gave himself another win, this time over Daren Fung, to make the score - before Ricky Hull pulled one back for Fitzpatrickrsquos with a victory over Chris Gordon.Andy Degean ensured it would be Collinsrsquo who came away with the points after he secured the win over Paul Craig.SAVAGErsquoS..........................................MIRABELLE A................................JOHNNY Craig kicked off proceedings with a win for his Mirabelle side over Reece McCormick before Jay Greavy squared up the scoreline with a victory over Shane McQuoid.Shay Blaney gave Savagersquos the lead after he defeated Pat McQuoid, but once again the scores went level whenThomas Curran overcame Declan Morgan.Savagersquos managed to pull out in front again, this time courtesy of William Duncanrsquos win over Dee Sharvin.However, the match settled with a fair share of the spoils after Stephen Sloan nabbed the win from Aaron McCarthyARKLE BAR....................................FITZPATRICKrsquoS A...........................DERMOT Feenan began his Arkle sidersquos four game win streak with a victory over Sean McCabe in the opening match-up.Gabriel Hogg defeated Mick Galbraith to extend the lead, before Tony Murray made it a hat-trick of wins with his win over Stefan McConvey.Arklersquos Dennis Feenan overcame James McGrath, before Fitzpatrickrsquos finally got off the mark as Mick Galbraith defeated Anthony Gilchrist.The result was already confirmed, but Fitzpatrickrsquos continued to battle and to his credit Stefan McConvey defeated James Keenan in the final game of the night.This weekrsquos fixtures: Mirabelle A v Fitzpatrickrsquos B, Savagersquos v Mirabelle B, Arkle v Round House.prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch put five past Antrim
story: BALLYNAHINCH men faced Antrim for the second time this season and ran out - winners in an excellent display of hockey at the weekend.The opening quarter started with a lsquoHinch pushback, with the ball being played around the back four and midfield.Matthew Martin passed back to Rea Coffey, who had some super runs up the right wing, before playing the ball round the back to Andrew Mulholland and Leslie Harrison.With both teams fighting hard for every ball, possession was going to play a key part in the game.Ashley Brown made a super pass up to Josh Higginson on the left wing, who had a brilliant cross into the Antrim circle that was just narrowly missed by Zak Patterson.With Antrim on the attack, they began pressing forward with lot of men. Antrim were able to break in the lsquoHinch circle several times only to be stopped by some brilliant defending by the back four.lsquoHinch were able to press up the pitch with some great put together passes from Craig Harkness to Jason Campbell and Scott Leetch, who were able to win a short corner.Ballynahinch were soon able to win another short corner after a deflection off an Antrim foot. Matthew Martin managed to slip the ball past the Antrim defence with a drag flick to give his side the lead.With Antrim looking to equalise the game, they began pressing hard and were rewarded with a short corner. The shot was saved by Martin, who was able to play the ball out of the circle, to end the first quarter.As the second quarter commenced, the lsquoHinch men began committing men forward on the attack that included a superb pass from Scott Leetch up to Jason Campbell, only to be denied with a great save from the Antrim lsquokeeper.Antrimrsquos forward broke in to the lsquoHinch circle, although he was met by lsquokeeper Aaron Donnell who saved the shot smartly.Andrew Mulholland had some long runs, beating Antrim defenders in the process, before passing the ball to Jason Campbell, who slipped the ball to Craig Harkness on the flick, scoring Hinchrsquos second goal of the day.Antrim were not going to give up easily, although came under more pressure when Ashley Brown threw an aerial to Jason Campbell, who was stopped in his tracks by the opposing defender.The third quarter began with Adam Dodds tackling the Antrim midfield before crossing the ball to Jason Campbell to get on the score sheet taking it to -.However, Antrim were determined to keep lsquoHinch from extending their lead even further with some great tackles and team play.Both teams were able to create chances but neither could convert until lsquoHinchrsquos resilience paid off once more.Scott Leetchrsquos pass up to Lewis Higginson allowed him to hit the ball to the back post for Andrew McIlwaine to tap in.The final quarter included end to end play from both teams for the first few minutes, but once they had settled back in to the game, lsquoHinch started to build.The play continued with Ashley Brown throwing an aerial up the pitch, that was brought down safely by Matthew Martin to score his second goal of the match. This quarter continued with Hinch applying pressure in the Antrim  and trying to increase the score.However, the scoring was completed in what was a one sided affair.Well done to Aaron Donnell and his defence on their first clean sheet of the season.Ballynahinch extend their thanks to all their supporters and to the umpires, as well as the Primrose Ballynahinch for their continued sponsorship.The player of the match was Ashley Brown..prettyPhoto

title: Chance to send letters to Santa in Glasswater Wood
story: EAGER children are visiting Glasswater Wood just outside Crossgar to post their Christmas letters to Santa Claus.A new Santa Claus post box in the woods has become a destination for local families enjoying a country walk as their childrenrsquos excitement builds for the big day ndash with a promise that all letters will go to Lapland.Itrsquos the brainchild of local grandfather-of-four Michael McClements, who created the post box to entertain and please local children.Michael, who runs McClements Construction of Crossgar, said he created the post box out of gas cylinders with help from several local businesses.Itrsquos his latest kind and generous gesture following his creation of wooden houses which he has put on ious trees which tell the stories of the Gruffalo, The Three Little Pigs and other popular childrenrsquos stories.Micheal explained: ldquoI began to make the little houses for the entertainment of my grandchildren as something to do during the last lockdown and thought I would put them on the trees at Glasswater Wood. For many local families, getting out for a walk with the children was the only activity they could do at that time.ldquoMy grandchildren really enjoyed seeing the little houses in the woods and they encouraged me to make more. I thought the Santa Claus post box would be good too and Irsquom glad to say that dozens of little children are already posting their letters into the box since it went up last week.Michael used old gas cylinders to make the Santa Claus head and body and a steel funnel for the hat.He was helped by John Killen, of Abbeyview Engineering, who welded the pieces together, Kenny Martin, who shotblasted and painted it, and Philip Houston, of Get Noticed Signs, who did all the signs for the post box and the cartoon graphics for the boxes.Michael said: ldquoI have to thank everyone who helped me out and give of their time and work freely all in aid to help the children enjoy the woods and the run-up to Christmas.ldquoWhen Irsquom walking my grandchildren, they run from box to box and they love to see the fairy tales and I get as much out of it when I see other little children running along as well.ldquoIrsquom told by some other parents and grandparents that it used to be hard to get their children out for a walk and now they are being asked to go for a walk all the time. Irsquom delighted that all the children are enjoying this..prettyPhoto

title: Down Leisure Centre closed over boiler issue
story: CONTRACTORS are working to resolve a technical problem which has resulted in the closure of the Down Leisure Centre since last Saturday.It is unclear when Newry, Mourne and Down Council will reopen the poundm Market Street complex in Downpatrick, with officials insisting that the doors will only open to staff and the public when it is safe to do so.The closure was enforced when staff discovered smoke coming from a boiler mdash which heats the multi-million pound complex mdash during their daily pre-opening checks last Saturday.The Fire and Rescue Service was alerted as a precaution, but it is understood that the smoke was caused by a build-up from a blockage.As a result, council officials called in specialist safety contractors who have been working to carry out a thorough check of the equipment to ensure that this is fixed.Council officials have confirmed that the reopening of the leisure centre depends on the outcome of the consultantsrsquo work and the availability of certain parts to ensure all safety standards are met.Downpatrick area councillor, Gareth Sharvin, said the publicrsquos safety is ldquoparamount and that the leisure complex will reopen when it is deemed safe.ldquoWhile no-one wants Down Leisure Centre to be close, it can only reopen when it is completely safe for the public and staff to use it, he said.ldquoI know that the council is working hard through its specialist contractors to ensure that and I would hope that any leisure centre member with cancelled classes or whatever will be compensated by the council as it is able to do so.A local authority spokesman confirmed that leisure centre customers will continue to be updated about the closure, with discounts provided to compensate for the number of days the facility was closed.He said the centrersquos heating system had ldquoexperienced an unforeseen mechanical issue.The spokesman added: ldquoTo ensure the safety and wellbeing of the general public Newry, Mourne and Down Council has decided to close the leisure centre until the heating system can be fully repaired.ldquoAll of the safety mechanisms in place ensured that the mechanical fault was detected quickly, and the Fire and Rescue Service did attend as a precaution. Council staff continue to work with contractors to resolve the issue to ensure the Down Leisure Centre reopens as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick autism group secures £45k lottery fund boost
story: THE Downpatrick Autism Family Support Group has been awarded pound, by the National Lottery Community Fund.The cash boost is part of a poundm allocation to almost  groups across Northern Ireland mdash including the Rowallane Community Hub mdash which was confirmed this week.Officials with the Downpatrick group say the money will be used to run activities for children and young people with autism and for parents and carers of children and young people on the autism spectrum or who are awaiting a possible diagnosis.The three-year project will help children and young people learn coping techniques and develop relationships, while reducing stress for parents carers and offering respite.Planned activities will include an annual fun day, occupational therapy sessions, drama sessions, social skills sessions, mental health programmes, yoga, and parenting training.The Rowallane Community Hub, which was awarded pound,, plans to use the money to set up a Henrsquos Shed to provide women a space of their own and the opportunity to come together and develop new skills and build relationships across the local community.The National Lottery Community Fundrsquos Northern Ireland chairman, Paul Sweeney, said he was proud to see the amazing impact that money raised by National Lottery players is having in communities across Northern Ireland.He added: ldquoThis funding is supporting a erse range of projects, who are meeting the needs in our local communities. Irsquom looking forward to seeing how these projects help people to rebuild and thrive.For more information on National Lottery funding visit our website www.tnlcommunityfund.org.uk funding northern-ireland or social media..prettyPhoto

title: East Down runners at Forest Park
story: TOLLYMORE Forest Park was the venue for a multi distance event at the weekend, organised by  Extreme.While the scenery is an obvious attraction to the runners, they come in the knowledge that that they will face several hills and off road terrain, so it is not a race for those who like to chase times and personal bests.As per previous years, there was a K, a half marathon, a full marathon and an ultra marathon all on offer with East Down AC represented in both the K and the full marathon .With four races and routes it could have been confusing but for those doing the half marathondistance, it was a one loop course which the marathonersthen did twice.For those doing the ultra marathon it was a case of back round for a third time. The races also had dfering start times with the longer distances starting earlier in the day.Doing laps often keeps the runners compact in terms of marshalling and spectating but it can mean that those doing the longer distances are tested mentally when they see others finishing.It is sometimes hard to carry on for the next loop when you can see others reaching the end of their efforts. It also means where there is a hill or a tricky part of the race, you will see it more than onceyou are doing the marathon or the ultra. The k route was slightly separate but also included a few steep sections so it was not an easy option by any means.Marguerite Robinson had been training hard to regain fitness after a layoff with injury and had hoped to be ready to use her half marathon slot, which was a deferred entry from last yearrsquos event, that was called off due to Covid- restrictions.However, as race day approached, she realised that on this occasion that she might be taking on more than she could chew and certainly more than she would enjoy so she wisely switched to the K.She was easy with her decision once the race got underway and even more so during the last mile when she was running the drag uphill from the gate to the finish. She completed in . and was th female .Declan Teague has been in fine marathon form recently, packing in three such races in short succession from September into October, but this one was notable as it got him to number  in his tally.Unfortunately since his last race, he has had to reduce his training miles due to niggles and he arrived at the start line knowing that he was going to have to dig deep to get round.He was therefore delighted to hook up with Phillip Vint as the race got underway and said that the camaraderie took their mind off the big climbs and got them through the first hour with ease.Phillip was on his way to his th marathon and in his usual understated fashion he was just there to get on with it.The commitment and consistency of these guys has to be admired.As much as Declan was enjoying the company, he urged Phillip to press on to pursue his own pace. Phillip very gradually eased away over the miles ahead and finished a superb th overall in three hours and  minutes.This would be a commendable time on tarmac let alone on an off road event. Declan stuck to his own rhythm and was happy with his time of . which placed him nd out of the  who completed.Clare Carson was also in for the marathon distance and taking it in her stride she dipped in just under the five hours to add another one to the long list that she is accumulating.They all commented that they found the downhills as tough as the ups and the quad muscles had definitely taken a battering, but despite the testing route, it is one they will likely repeat.Stephen Heasley, who was in Tollymore to take part in the ultra distance, reported back that he was a lsquoDNFrsquo. For those of you who are unsure what DNF means, it is short for lsquodid not finishrsquo.Most would assume that this would be a major disappointment.In Stephenrsquos case though, perhaps it would be more accurate to say that he had a change of plan rather than a failure.Although he was finding it tough going, he waited until the end of lap two to call it a day so in fact he completed a marathon while considering his options.For many of us managing to finish a marathon on a good day would be a challenge. To do so on a ldquobad day seems almost a triumph.It was certainly the right decision for Stephen on the day and hopefully he will now take time for recovery before his next escapade.Jonny Holmes had taken part in the NIMAA XC Championships a month ago as a way of trying his hand at cross country running.That event also stood as selection for the NI team for the North South Challenge. Based on the results that day, the Masters Association drew up teams of six plus one reserve for each age group -, -, - and so on.Jonny was duly notied that he was picked to run as reserve in the - category and so he turned up at Queens Playing Fields last Saturday, slightly concerned as to how he would cope given the standard of the runners.He had no need to worry as he paced it well and did himself and the club proud.He was rd in the end and completed the five lap muddy circuit in  odd minutes. He expressed his awe of the standard at the front of the race and felt that it was great to have the experience of being part of such a competitive event.This weekend sees the cross country season continue with a large EDAC squad heading to Comber for the Comber Cup and some juniors travelling to Santry in Dublin for the All-Ireland Even Age Group Championships as part of the Co Down team. Good luck to all concerned..prettyPhoto

title: Famous Tropicana slide facing demolition in leisure overhaul
story: NEWCASTLErsquoS famous Tropicana swimming poolrsquos outdoor slide is to be demolished as part of a major new plan to signicantly improve leisure facilities in the resort.The work will be carried out in tandem with the demolition of the auditorium extension at the rear of the Newcastle Centre in a pound, project discussed by councillors in private on Monday evening.Itrsquos believed that the demolition of the slide will result in the permanent closure of the family pool, with suggestions that some form of indoor pool provision will be included in the planned new multi-million pound leisure and community facility.It is understood that the full cost of the ambitious Newcastle Centre redevelopment plan is yet to be finalised by senior council officials.A detailed feasibility study undertaken earlier this year looked at a number of potential locations for a new leisure centre and suggested the Newcastle Centre site a firm favourite to house the new facility.Members of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Active and Healthy Communities committee rubber-stamped the capital project proposal on Monday night when it was also agreed to rehouse services provided in the auditorium within the existing centre.Redeveloping the existing centre on Central Promenade ndash which forms part of the Annesley Buildings ndash had been previously ruled out due to the scale of the costs involved.It is known that the listed building currently cannot accommodate the needs of local people due to the size of its rooms.Councill officials have previously confirmed that plans to redevelop the town centre site will not impact on part of the promenade at the rear.Senior council officials have previously acknowledged the problem of Newcastle not having a modern indoor facility as one of Northern Irelandrsquos premier tourist resorts.Also on Monday night, members of the Active and Healthy Communities Committee rubber-stamped a major reconfiguration of the Ballynahinch Community Centre.The work at the Windmill Street complex will help reconfigure the interior of the building to maximise space in order to allow more community activities to be held there..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  November 21%2C 2001
story: NEWCASTLE mdash An appeal has been made by members of a Newcastle pressure group for more community support to help in the fight to keep the Rock Pool open.The Friends of the Rock Pool group, which formed in January following the news that Down Council was considering closing the  year-old facility because of rising overheads and ain visitor numbers, held a special meeting on Wednesday night.The event was convened because just a handful of supporters attended the action grouprsquos last meeting in September.As a result of this low turnout, letters were sent to members telling them the previous meeting had been ldquovery poorly attended and the survival of the Rock Pool ldquowould not succeed on the efforts of three or four people.Speaking during the meeting, the grouprsquos chairwoman, Mary Hull, said the Friends of the Rock Pool would only continue to existmembers ldquoworked together as a group.ldquoThe core we had at the start has sadly fallen away and we need to regroup. Unless we have the backing of the public, Down Council could turn around and say they donrsquot think they should back us and this is why we are calling for additional numbers.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A senior police officer has this week appealed for an end of sectarian violence in Ballynahinch.The plea by Inspector Paul McClean come after Nationalists and Loyalists again clashed this weekend in a series of running battles in the market town.Trouble flared at The Square late on Friday night and continued into the early hours of Saturday, with police officers being pelted with stones and fireworks.Violence erupted after Nationalists were blamed for smashing the window of a pub used by Loyalists and at one point up to  people spilled out on to the streets and became embroiled in a number of fights.No one was seriously injured, but people attending aat the White Horse Hotel had to remain in the premises until am for police to clear the area.Additional police were deployed to help restore calm and appealing for an end to he trouble Inspector McClean urges people on both sides not to escalate the situation in the town.DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick is in line for another major housing development. Planning officials have this week approved the construction of  new houses.The homes, which are to be built at the disused quarry of Racecourse Hill, will be developed in tandem with  new car parking spaces.Details of the scheme, which is being proposed by the Downpatrick firm of OrsquoBoylersquos, were made public at Monday nightrsquos meeting of Down Council.News of the scheme has been welcomed by councillor Ann Trainor who believes the quarry will be transformed as a result of the ambitious scheme.Mrs Trainor said the quarry has become something of an eyesore over recent yeas and believes the new housing scheme will further enhance the regeneration of this key area in the town.She said that over the past number of years the nearby Flying Horse and Model Farm housing estates have been transformed and is confident the quarry area at the Racecourse Hill is also set for a new lease of le.ARDGLASS ndash Armed robbers made off with several hundred pounds from a fish processing factory in Ardglass on Friday morning.At around . am two men, one armed with a sawn-off shotgun, burst into the office at Milliganrsquos factory at the harbour and ordered staff to lie on the floor.The men then took the cash float, which police have confirmed was several hundred pounds, before making off in a silver coloured vehicle.The gunman has been described as around  or  years of age, approximately rsquorsquorsquo tall, with a round face and of medium build. He was dressed in a white hooded boiler suit and was wearing trainers and possibly a woollen hat.The second robber was about rsquorsquorsquo tall, of a slim or medium build and with short dark hair. Both men, who had Belfast accents, sped of in the silver vehicle, which was later found abandoned in the Meadow Court area of Ardglass. It has been reported stolen from Killyleagh.CASTLEWELLAN ndash A senior Sinn Fein politician has called for those responsible for the weekend attack on the Castlewellan republican memorial to stop ldquocausing heartache for the families of the IRA dead.Assembly man Mick Murphyrsquos comments came this week after the controversial Lower Square memorial was vandalised late on Friday night or in the early hours of Saturday.The Celtic cross which dominated the memorial, was severely damaged and hda to be removed leaving only the plinth on which the names of the dad republicans are etched.The memorial to commemorate ten IRA members killed during the Troubles was officially unveiled on Sunday, September .Mr Murphy called on those responsible for the attack to come forward so he can ask them why this was done as he believes ldquothere has been enough suffering in both communities.The Assemblyman added: ldquoWhile this monument may not have been everyonersquos cup of tea, the reality is that it was a monument to people who died in pursuit of freedom in Ireland, he said.SAINTFIELD ndash Subtle changes which have helped transform a number of businesses in the heart of Saintfieldrsquos conservation area were detailed during a special briefing session in the town last week.Representatives from the business community joined property owners and members of Saintfield Town Committee for a progress report on the continuing work to regenerate a number of key buildings.The work forms part of an ambitious townscape heritage initiative which is currently underway in the market town along with other similar schemes in Downpatrick and Killough.The White Horse Inn, one of the oldest buildings in Saintfield and which itself has featured heavily in the heritage initiative, was the setting for the progress report delivered by Mrs Harriet Devlin.The Saintfield Town Committee official, who is heavily involved in the project, paid tribute to the ious business and home owners who played key roles in helping to regenerate their respective premises.She said the work has transformed the conservation area and said while not all the schemes involved major building work, they did succeed in raising the profile of the historic town.KILLYLEAGH ndash Killyleagh Community Playgroup has been wrongly praised by Department of Education inspectors.In a recently published report the inspectors praised the happy, family atmosphere and found the relationships between staff and children were very good.The inspectors said the staff provide the children with high levels of support and reassurance which help the children grow in confidence and independence.Accommodation at the playgroup, which is based at the Bridge Centre, is good and staff make effective use of available space.ldquoThe staff are hardworking: their commitment is evident in the daily preparation of an attractive learning environment which is set out into distinct areas of play and is enhanced by displays of the childrenrsquos work, photographs and books, said the report.KILLOUGH ndash A grain store in Killough is to be converted into a new dwelling.The scheme, which borders Main Street and Palatine Square, is being proposed by the villagersquos Palatine Trust.It has been given the green light by local planners who have been told the move involves the redevelopment of part of an existing stable block.DUNDRUM ndash A new holiday cottage is to be constructed in Dundrum.Planning officials have this week approved the development which will include the demolition of a number of existing buildings at Castle Hill.Following the demolition, the rubble is to be reused in the construction of the new holiday cottage, which in addition to stone walls will also feature a slated roof..prettyPhoto

title: Hoops advance to Dalzell Cup final
story: CELTIC Bhoys marched into the final of the Bobby Dalzell Cup with a comprehensive victory over local rivals Killough at a windswept Ballyhornan on Friday night.Two goals in each half, including a brace from Celtic striker Jay Gibney, was enough to ensure it would be the Hoops who would be contending for this yearrsquos title on December .To both teams credit, the number of supporters that flooded through the gates to watch this spectacle was more than commendable, with hundreds of people in attendance to witness what is historically a feisty encounter between the sides mdash this occasion being no dferent.Killough, donning their new kit, kicked off, but in a matter of moments found themselves defending a free-kick in a dangerous area, although Celtic centre back Gary Carberry saw his effort well saved by lsquokeeper Christopher Mallon.The opening minutes played out to a rapid pace of football, with the wind unsure of which direction to blow resulting in both teams attempting to play on the ground.Killoughrsquos first big opportunity came courtesy of a Connor Kelly free-kick after team-mate Cillian Burns was pulled down by defender Blaine Connolly unfairly.However, Kellyrsquos effort just whisked over the crossbar in what would prove to be a seldom chance for the village side in the opening  minutes.What Celtic seemed to have in their arsenal which Killough lacked was showing clinical precision and accuracy from their set pieces.With seven minutes on the clock, the Hoops would have their first of  corners throughout the match, with the Killough defence failing to clear the danger with any conviction, allowing the ball to float back across the box and into the path of Celtic marksman Jay Gibney.The striker made no mistake with the finish and the deadlock was broken.Referee James McCreesh certainly had his work cut out, as he consistently gave verbal warnings to both teams and their management as he did a commendable job controlling the pace of the contest.However, his patience was tested one too many times and after a quarter of an hour, Killoughrsquos Kevin Groves received the first yellow card of the game for a tackle on Gerard Collins.Celticrsquos Peter Casey struck the resultant free and was unlucky to see his effort kiss the top of the crossbar.The Hoops continued their pressure and were rewarded with a corner. Barry Treacy, whose set piece efforts were fantastic throughout the  minutes, stepped up to strike a low cross into the box for captain Mikey Rice to tap in and double his sidersquos lead.Rice was instrumental for Celtic and deservedly was awarded man of the match for his efforts.A manic couple of minutes ensued after another corner caused Killough problems, the ball this time falling to Casey who saw his left-footed effort crash off the underside of the crossbar and somehow away to safety.Celtic kept their relentless efforts in attack and a moment later they thought they had their third, but their strike was ruled out for offside. Killough then failed to properly dispatch the ball up the pitch, allowing Hoopsrsquo striker Jordan McCoubrey to attack their goal.However, McCoubrey was left frustrated when his appeal for a penalty was waved off by McCreesh.Killoughrsquos Declan Burns received a booking for a hearty tackle on the opposition before team-mate and lsquokeeper Mallon managed to ert the ball away from the net in a dramatic goal line scramble.In what was an admittedly underwhelming performance by Killough, custodian Mallon made a number of inspiring saves throughout the match and kept the final score at a much more respectable tally.Celticrsquos Casey must have thought he had been the subject of a curse, after his third long ranged effort in the space of  minutes struck the woodwork, this time a spectacular  yard effort thumping against the upper left.Killough managed to weather the storm and their best chance of the half came from captain Gareth Georgersquos free-kick which sailed wide of the post before Celticrsquos Connolly picked up a yellow card for a combination of fouls.That signalled the last signicant action of the opening  as Celtic led by two at the half-time interval.Upon the restart, Shaun Megahey managed to sneak past the Killough backline to force a point blank range save from Mallon as changes were made to both sides, including the introduction of Stephen Galbraith for the Hoops.Carberry was the latest entry into the book after dragging down Killoughrsquos Kelly before the village side suffered an injury blow in the form of midfielder Matt McKiernan on the hour mark.The game had settled down at this point, with Killough still deciding whether to stick or twist as they knew they needed a goal, but one wrong move and the game would be put beyond their reach.Mallon continued to impress in goals, with an eye-catching one handed save off a Carberry header, although at the th minute the result was put beyond doubt.A calamity of errors in the Killough defence allowed Gibney to square the ball to substitute Galbraith, who tapped into the open net to completely crush their opponentsrsquo fighting spirit.Killough are known for their resilience and kept fighting to the conclusion, but it was clear that it wouldnrsquot be their day as the clock wound down.Megahey picked up a yellow for the Hoops before his opponents saw a penalty appeal for a hand ball shut down.Tempers continued to flair as Killoughrsquos Ruairi Sharvin added his name to the list of yellow card recipients just before his sidersquos misery compounded when Gibney added Celticrsquos fourth of the match with a neatly struck finish.Killough resorted to shooting from distance but werenrsquot having much luck, with Jack McLoughlinrsquos effort the only to really cause Celtic custodian Nathan Curran to spring into action with a confident one handed save.Groves did manage to loop a headed effort past Curran. However, as per the theme of the match, Celticrsquos defence managed to clear the ball before it could cross the line.McCreesh blew his whistle for the final time to send the Celtic fans into raptures as the players audibly voiced their pleasure at making yet another final.Man of the match and Hoopsrsquo skipper Mikey Rice gave his thoughts on the performance after the contest.ldquoEveryone knows what theyrsquore getting with Celtic Bhoys and Killough, big hits, hard tackles and a great spectacle for the neutral, he said.ldquoYou see the amount of people who came down here, especially for the Newcastle league teams, itrsquos brilliant. It was always going to be a great game and I respect Killough a lot, he continued.ldquoI think there was a few people here watching the match who will be featuring in next weekrsquos semi-final between Dundrum and Ardglass, so hopefully we gave them a wee bit of fear to face us.Celtic Bhoys: N Curran S Megahey, B Connolly, G Carberry M Rice , G Collins, B Treacy, P Casey, J Gibney, J McCoubrey, N Williams-McCabe.Subs: C Kerr, S Galbraith, S McMahon, C McCartan.Killough: C Mallon, S Og Burns, G George , E Gargan, R Sharvin, M McKiernan, D Burns, K Groves, C Burns, C Kelly, J McLoughlin.Subs: D Looney, T McIlhone, L Murphy, R Burns, D Taggart.Yellow cards: K Groves, D Burns, R Sharvin.Corners: Celtic Bhoys , Killough .Offsides: Celtic Bhoys , Killough ..prettyPhoto

title: Lease signing paves way for ambitious investment at Castlewellan Forest Park
story: LOCAL politicians have formally approved an agreement which paves the way for a major multi-million pound investment in Castlewellan Forest Park.Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Forest Service have signed a draft lease which legally formalises the local authorityrsquos phased takeover of the stunning forest park which attracts tens of thousands of visitors yearly.A pound.m revitalisation project at the park is being backed by the National Lottery Heritage Fund and the local council, with the latter spearheading the ambitious project to signicantly enhance facilities at the sprawling park, with the lottery funding earmarked to restore a number of key features to help maximise its tourism potential.Construction work has already commenced at the Bothy Yard thanks to funding from the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs and the EU.Work on the main restoration project is scheduled to complete by December , with the local authority agreeing a lease for the core areas within the park from the Forest Service until .Proposed work includes new landscape and drainage within The Grange courtyard, a new pedestrian path from the entrance gates to the main car park, a new vehicular road off Castle Avenue to the existing car park. There will also be a new traffic control barrier at Castle Avenue.Caravan spaces will be relocated with the feature entrance gates at the Castle Avenue entrance restored, alongside the restoration of The Grange courtyard buildings and the reconstruction of a derelict building block.The parkrsquos th century greenhouse is also being restored with the reconstruction of the propagation house and cold frames, while one of several outbuildings will be converted to an office and volunteer space.Elsewhere, visitor facilities will be created in the Stove Conservatory including an interpretation centre, with a  lt installed to provide access to the terrance for people with reduced mobility.Agreement on the draft lease came at a recent meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Tourism and Regeneration Committee with the news welcomed by South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillors High Gallagher and Laura Devlin.Mr McGrath said plans to signicantly invest in the park will be a ldquogame changer for the South Down area.He said the cocktail of funding which has been secured to finance the revitalisation project will transform the built and natural heritage of the sprawling forest park andact as a huge pull for visitors to the area.Cllr Gallagher said he was delighted that the lease issue had been resolved and that the project was progressing.ldquoAs a Castlewellan councillor, this project is huge and will bring so much benefit to the wider area, he continued.ldquoThis same lease confirmed that the very popular lsquotouring in the treesrsquo permit for touring caravan owners will remain in Forest Service control until the end of . This was an issue that was raised with me and many local businesses in Castlewellan.Cllr Gallagher said that after , the local authority will assume responsibility for lsquotouring in the treesrsquo and that the local authorityrsquos senior management team recognises the importance of this longstanding tradition continuing.Cllr Devlin said that as a Castlewellan resident and a member of the forest park revitalisation project board, agreeing the draft lease represented a huge step, one she described as ldquohugely signicant.She added: ldquoThis project has been underway for many years and so much work, time and effort has been exerted by council officers, all of the ious agencies, elected members and project board chairperson Sally Montgomery.ldquoTo see all of this work now materialise is superb. I more or less grew up in the forest park as a child and it was so disheartening to see its deterioration over the years so this is one particular project that I am very excited about.Cllr Devlin extended a ldquohuge thanks to everyone who played a signicant part in getting the project to this stage and looks forward to seeing further developments on the ground..prettyPhoto

title: Lions go contactless
story: NEWCASTLE Lions Club have invested in a mobile contactless card payment device for use with their Christmas collections.The card reader was purchased with donations from Lions members and will ensure that % of all donations will go to charity.Club president Liz Murphy hopes themachine will be a success and stresses that the mobile card payment will be set for a pound donation.The card reader card can be used as a contactless or pin number device. President Liz also would like to stress that cash donations are also very much welcome.Newcastle Lions Club who have joined with other Lion clubs including Newry, Banbridge, Ballynahinch, Armagh and Downpatrick, who are working hard to raise as much funds as possible for local foodbanks.The appeal will end on December  when all collected funds will be split six ways equally for the foodbanks in each of the six towns.The public are also encouraged to donate to the foodbanks appeal by logging on to www.lionsnewcastlecodown.org and clicking on the DONATE button.Newcastle Lions would like to thank the recent donation of pound through this facility..prettyPhoto

title: Minister hears about learning experiences after lockdown
story: EDUCATION Minister Michelle McIlveen was in Downpatrick last Wednesday.Ms McIlveen visited St Patrickrsquos Grammar School and Down High School.Her first port of call was St Patrickrsquos where she toured the school and met Art students and the Saphara Group as they planned their fund-raising initiatives to support the work of the charity in India.After seeing the schoolrsquos memorial garden, the Minister had an informal cup of tea with members of the schoolrsquos leadership team, as well as the head boy, Patrick Gordon, and the head girl, Eva Rowan.She was interested to hear about their experience of learning during the pandemic, their thoughts on assessment, the Shared Education programme with Down High School and their work as part of the Eco Council.She was told about the impact of the current situation on learning and teaching and their plans and hopes for the future.Ms McIlveen also learned about the schoolrsquos plans to work towards achieving the Wellbeing Award for Schools.St Patrickrsquos has undertaken this award to continue to promote wellbeing and good mental health.The award involves the school demonstrating a clear strategy that promotes and protects emotional wellbeing and mental health, in both students and staff.In the last few weeks, the views of students, parents and staff, regarding how the school promotes and supports mental health and wellbeing, havebeen sought via an online questionnaire and the newly appointed lsquoChange Teamrsquo are now drawing up an action plan.The school principal, Mr Joe McCann said the team was ldquolooking forward to putting in place all the measures we possibly can to optimise wellbeing and mental health for the entire Red High family which continues to be a priority as we come out the other side of the pandemic.At Down High Ms McIlveen was greeted by the stirring skirl of the bagpipes by Year  pupil Alex McSpadden, followed by a rendition of The Parting Glass by IsabellaKelly on harp and her sister, Maya, on violin.After meeting informally with the student leadership team over refreshments, the minister discussed a range of issues with the chairwoman of the board of governors, Mrs Avril Heenan, Mrs Maud Perry, principal, Mr Ken Dawson, deputy principal, and Mr Gareth McKillen, vice-principal for pastoral care.Among the items discussed were the recent progress in Down High Schoolrsquos new build.Enabling works, halted during the pandemic, resumed in April  and the project was issued for tender in October.After a tour of the school site, the minister said she appreciated the urgent need for state of the art facilities for the pupils and teachers for a school that is thriving despite sub-standard premises.Ms McIlveen also discussed the ongoing impact that the pandemic was having on qualications and the mental health of young people.Mrs Perry said afterwards: ldquoIt was lovely to meet with the minister today. We are all very grateful that she took time out of her busy schedule to connect with our school first hand.ldquoAt a time when uncertainty surrounds so many aspects of education it was obvious that the minister listens, shows empathy and has the interests of young people at the core of what she does..prettyPhoto
